Make no mistake, the developers have really outdone themselves with this gem, and you'd be a fool to pass this up if you're a fan of any rpg. You'll find yourself dropped into an artistically woven world of challenges, rewards, out-of-context humor, and adventure. The separate classes are well balanced to create a different experience every time you replay it.

This attempt at recapturing the charm of old-school Ultima shows potential at first, but soon falls flat on its face. Exploration is suppossed to be the main focus, but exploring the world isn't rewarding. The interface for combat is stunningly bad, to the point that any enemy that's not a complete pushover is an exercise in frustration. Meanwhile, loot is randomized and class-restricted, meaning 70-90% of what you find is useless except to sell for gold. So the game soon becomes a slog, and the lack of basic player conveniences like fast travel doesn't help. The last straw is the dungeons; overlong, confusing, and packed with absurdly hard foes, they soon try the patience of even the most obsessive rpg fan. At least the developer avoided ads and pay-to-win shenanigans. Unfortunately, that noble decision doesn't make the game fun.

The conversations with non-player characters are somewhat linear, but don't let that stop you--this game is a lot of fun.  Great for killing an hour on the metro during commute.  BTW, like MANY games, this game will not run on Lollipop.  (I highly recommend against Lollipop for at least a few more months. Totally screwed up my Nexus 5.  Luckily Google is kind enough to make it easy to flash your Nexus back to KitKat.)  Update:  This game will not install on the Nvidia Shield Tablet.  Kind of a bummer.  I'm not sure if this is a Nvidia problem or a Valorware problem. Seems like the developer could hire some help to iron out the kinks.  Probably easier said than done.  Nevertheless a great game. A great game that nails a lot of what I've been wanting in a mobile rpg.  The sense of freedom and exploration is great.  There are a few of things I hope get addressed in the sequel:  1) The nearly useless hotbars, due to their button placement.  If I have to jam something more than once to get it to work, then it's not a useable hotbar. 2)  Multiple outcomes for quests.  There are elements in Jinko's quest (which is probably the best quest in the game) that do this, but for the most part they are all linear.  Introduce some choice into the outcome of quests, preferably with moral quandaries involved, and have the different outcomes bestow different benefits on the player or affect the world in different ways.  3)  Ditch the easter-egg treasure hunt approach to quests.  Not a fan of scouring the entire world map for 7 treasures for which no clue is given as to their location.  This quest could have been made much more satisfying by placing meaningful location clues throughout the world... dialogue with characters referring to these treasures would've been nice.  This gives in-game context to the quest, and it feels less like a random checklist.

9th Dawn is a very well put together game that mixes some of the best qualities of our favorite RPG games into one. The graphics are superb and offer nostalgic gameplay void of any hiccups. Action and movement are simple, fun, and challenging. You won't find a game with such polished sound either.   If you're a fan of titles like Diablo,  Planescape, Zelda, or Baldur's you might just find a little of every game in 9th Dawn.  The only areas of improvement would be added character customization (dyes, more differences in item appearance, sex, etc.), character progressions (varying skill per level, increasing str to wear heavier armor, etc.), and new classes (rogue -> archer/thief -> ranger/marksman/assassin/master thief as opposed to knight/archer/mage).  Overall: 8.5/10 - MUST buy! Graphics: 8/10 Sound: 10/10 Gameplay: 8/10 Story: 7/10 Performance: 10/10

content: Seriously good game. I especially love the control scheme, which makes you feel more in direct control of the character than the point-and-click control scheme of most Android RPGs do. I actually felt like I was swinging a dagger at my enemies and drawing an arrow (I was playing an archer character). Well polished, though simple, graphics and a great soundtrack, making it a subtle yet immersive gaming experience. I just wish there is a way to freeze the game, because I'll be playing this game pretty often when commuting to work/school.

This is by far the best RPG on the Android Market. The mix of modern dual stick controls and the retro open world RPG is perfect. I can't wait to see what future updates bring to this already great game. Keep up the great work guys!
You can feel the love in this game. Its just AWESOME! One thing i found is that my magic projectile sometimes gets stuck in the walls.

Just forced myself to take a break to review this game. Even as a first release this game is massive in more ways than one. Huge world, lots of loot, quests, this game has it all with room for improvement as this is constantly updated as well.

Finaly a proper RPG for Android, thanks guys.
